questions.question_text: Which statement about switch access ports is true?

discussion.content: The correct answer is A:They drop packets with 802.1Q tags
The correct answer is A:They drop packets with 802.1Q tags

choices.C: They can receive traffic from more than one VLAN with no voice support.
choices.B: A VLAN must be assigned to an access port before it is created.
choices.D: By default, they carry traffic for VLAN 10.

questions.question_text: Which command shows your active Telnet connections?

discussion.content:
correct answer is C. see the listing below. "0 con 0" show direct connection (via console cable), and "390 vty 0" show connection via telnet from 1.1.1.1.

Router#show users 
 Line User Host(s) Idle Location
* 0 con 0 idle 00:00:00 
 390 vty 0 idle 00:00:26 1.1.1.1

 Interface User Mode Idle Peer Address
Router#
Correct answer is B. Pls don't misguide users.thnx

comments.content:
Connect to R2 from R1 via telnet. Once stablished the Telnet session, press ctrl+shift+6 (release them) and press X key immediatly, now issue "show session" command (on R1) and see the session you've just opened from R1 to R2.
Answer B is correct.
F is correct. You need to use straight through cables to connect Switch to Router, Router makes ROAS function so that both VLAN10 and VLAN20 be able to communicate with each other.

discussion.content: This question has something wrong or missing... but the answer is not F. We can't configure the same vlan on two different fisical interfaces or subinterfaces. I think the answer that best fits is A, a cross-over cable between the two switches.

questions.question_text: Which two states are the port states when RSTP has converged? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A and B are true
RSPT change from Blocking State to Discarding State
and Don't have Listening State

questions.question_text: The company internetwork is subnetted using 29 bits. Which wildcard mask should be used to configure an extended access list to permit or deny access to an entire subnetwork?

comments.content: stop thinking like that.. cf 11111000 v 00000111

Wildcard mask are always odd numbers. They can be determined by subtracting the subnet mask from 255.255.255.255.

255.255.255.255 - 255.255.255.248 = 0.0.0.7

You can think in the size of the network, then substract 1, that will be the wildcard mask. 
If subnetmask is /27 (255.255.255.224) then think, subnet size = 32 - 1 = 31. Wildcard = 0.0.0.31. Easy.

discussion.content:
I was thinking the correct answer is 0.0.0.8 and not 0.0.0.7
subtracting 248 from 256 will give 8
